 outgoing space travels, fastest spacecraft - NASA's Voyager 1, if traveling at its speed (17 km/s) for 70,000 years, would reach nearest star, alpha centauri, but more likely is in 40,000 years with nuclear pulsed propulsion.

Hello! let's explore the cosmos!
We are back with the second part of our thrilling adventure. Last time, we dived into the mysteries of exoplanets and discovered that the search for life might not be limited to our own solar system. In fact, the likelihood of other habitable planets existing in the universe has grown significantly in recent years.

Let's go a bit further – all the way to the nearest star, alpha centauri! imagine embarking on a space journey to the nearest star! 
probing the cosmos! according to NASA, a trip to alpha centauri, traveling at the speed of the Voyager 1 (17 km/s), would take over 70,000 years. however, with nuclear pulsed propulsion technology, this journey might be feasible in about 40,000 years. 
meanwhile, closer to home, scientists at NASA are constantly on the lookout for potential space destinations! the Kepler space telescope, particularly its second mission (K2), has been monitoring the universe, scanning thousands of stars. And guess what? Many Earth-sized planets have already been discovered orbiting nearby stars within the habitable zone, A.K.A. the 'Goldilocks zone'!

Imagine the possibilities of life thriving on these distant planets! wouldn't it be incredible to explore the mysteries of these planetary neighborhoods? the adventure continues, as we explore more unknowns in the cosmos...

check in next time for more thrilling cosmic discoveries! thanks for fellowshipping space explorers!
